resources.string: Where in the hospital are you conducting screening?"
If OPD Clinic or Ward, please specify
Is this child a patient or an attendant?
Does your child have a cough?
\nScreener Instructions: Inform the patient and the family member that you will now ask them questions to determine if your child should be further tested for TB or not.\n

Instructions: Carefully read A through E to determine if the child is a TB presumptive. 
 a. If the child has been in contact with someone with TB and has one or more symptoms then the child is a TB presumptive. 
 b. If the child has any 2 symptoms then patient is a TB presumptive. 
 c. If the child’s lymph node has been swollen for more than 2 weeks or if there is swelling in the bone or spine then the child is a TB presumptive. 
 d. If previous history of TB and any one symptom then child is a TB presumptive. 
 e. If the mother is a contact, then the child is a TB presumptive. 
 f. If all answers are no but the child is 5 year and below and has a TB patient contact at home then refer to MO for evaluation (for IPT)"
\nNurse Instructions: This form should be filled if the child\'s care giver has agreed to send the child to an MO.\n
\nMO Instructions: Kindly notify the patient of their next appointment date.\n
\nStaff Instructions: Kindly notify the patient of their next drug dispersal date.\n
The close contact has a history of cough for more than 2 weeks
Not responding to Nutritional Rehabiliation for 2 months
History of measles or whooping cough
Pulmonary Findings (unilateral wheeze, dullness, weight loss, Hepato-splenomegaly, Lymphadenopathy, ascites etc.
Matted lymph nodes, abdominal mass or doughy abdomen, sinus formation, gibbus formation, chronic mono arthritis, meningeal findings (bulging fontanel, irritability, choroid tubercle, papilloedema)
Ill-defined opacity or patchy infiltrates on chest X-Ray, Marked broncho-vascular marking.
Consolidation not responding to antibiotic therapy.
Para-tracheal, or mediastinal Lymphadenopathy, Miliary Mottling, cavitation, Tuberculoma on CAT/MRI brain, collapse vertebrae etc
Suggested Action: Investigate other reasons of illness
Suggested Action: Do not treat for TB, Manage the presenting symptom(s), Monitor monthly the condition(s) for 3 months using scoring chart
Suggested Action: Investigate and exclude other causes of illness, Investigation may justify therapy, if Xpert or Granuloma is positive then start treatment
Referral is when patient is referred before start of treatment. Transfer is when a patient is transferred out during treatment
\nScreener Instructions: Kindly guide the patient to the MO for further evaluation and testing\n

Does your child have fever for more than 2 weeks?

Has your child taken TB medication before?
